layers.name: BING-Layer

sidePanel.headerText: There are forms of civilization that have to disappear. You're looking at one. It's the Great River of Oil, known to Indigenous peoples as the Black Snake, rampant from the Tars Sands all the way to the Gulf of Mexico.
sidePanel.bodyText: Examine the vast energy systems of this world and ask yourself one question: What does "decarbonization" really mean? Does it mean ceasing to burn any fossil fuels whatsoever within thirty years—and therefore, dismantling entire industries starting right now? How to do that while maintaining livelihoods and avoiding civil war? Could restorative employment at the neighborhood level change some of the most basic rules of capitalist democracy? Could the results turn out better for everyone involved?

sidePanel.headerText: A map is an instrument of perception. It can expand your awareness of things around you.
sidePanel.bodyText: In the 2010's North America was overtaken by pipeline frenzy—and whenever it stalled in the courts, by explosive growth in oil-by-rail. In fact there had been an investment boom in everything petro: new drilling technologies, expanding refineries, pipelines reversing toward Gulf Coast ports, and proliferating natural gas infrastructure (including plastics and synthetic nitrogen galore). With fracking as well as regulatory rollback, the US became a net exporter of fossil fuels in the 2010s, while opening up mainline corridors for Canadian heavy oil production. The consequences of that decade—and maybe soon, its ruins—can be seen in every region. As energy prices strike pandemic lows and the entire shale-oil industry rolls over into bankruptcy, many people are wondering: Isn't there another way to prepare for onrushing climate change? What's society's next move?

sidePanel.headerText: The oil industry has held the world in political lockdown since the Seventies. Permanent war and climate change are the costs of cheap fuel.
sidePanel.bodyText:
Is it any wonder that a progressive left agenda seeks transformative investment in renewables? The aim is to find a pathway through the economic crash, toward a viable future. And it's not only a dream, it's a policy. The International Energy Agency aka World Bank calls for a Sustainable Recovery, which means they want to print billions of tokens to retool a way out of the crisis. The EU has embarked on its European Green Deal, which puts theory into practice. In the US, racial justice activists and climate campaigners are coming together around the Green New Deal launched by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and the Sunrise Movement.

Only grassroots pressure can keep these plans focused on the social and ecological outcomes. We have to push back against the dead weight of fossil bureaucracies—while collectively learning how to enter a restorative economy, and create a new energy system.

sidePanel.headerText: Coal power used to be progress. But it has made by far the largest contribution to CO2 levels in the atmosphere. Today, burning it is just suicidal—anywhere across the planet.
sidePanel.bodyText:
Coal still provides 24/7 baseline power to a grid that hasn't learned to deal with fluctating wind and solar. But in the United States and many other countries, the generation of electricity from coal has fallen dramatically over the last decade. Now is the time to phase it out entirely, while protecting the communities who depended on the industry.

The map shows the remaining coal plants with their characteristic geography, involving large cooling ponds, ash pools, and close access to river and/or rail transport. Coal is still extracted from a plethora of underground and surface mines in the Midwest and Northeast, and from a smaller number of far more productive ones in Wyoming. Why maintain an increasingly automated industry that promises to kill you and all other life on earth? Why not just take care of the workers by employing them on any of dozens of urgent projects?

sidePanel.headerText: Coal power used to be progress. But coal has made by far the largest contribution to CO<sup>2</sup> in the atmosphere. Today, coal burning is suicidal across the world
sidePanel.bodyText: In the United States, the generation of electricity from coal has fallen dramatically over the last decade. Now it's time to phase it out entirely while protecting the communities to which it has done so much damage in the recent past. The map shows the remaining coal plants along with all the known coal-ash ponds left alongside waterways throughout the United States. In a flood, the compacted ash can liquefy and spread a heavy charge of toxins through the land and the water.

sidePanel.headerText: What would it be like to build a new society?
sidePanel.bodyText:
When you least expect it we have an historic opportunity. The most expanionist pipelines have suddenly been stopped in the courts. Oil companies are falling into bankruptcy due to plunges in consumption. Investors are betting on solar and wind for the future. Insiders claim that fracking for crude is dust. If they're right, it's the end of an era in the Permian Basin and the Bakken—and hopefully the Tar Sands too. But halting the Sixth Mass Extinction needs more. It needs system change. With government investment, entire branches of the energy sector could be replaced outright. New kinds of hi-tech jobs would be created alongside community solar projects and pervasive retrofitting in the neighborhoods. Without that kind of meaningful employment, society would become a nightmare. But the point is to turn things in a different direction.

Now's the time. Before it's too late. In the midst of a breakdown we finally have a chance to do things entirely differently.
